a machine readable transcription

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Draft of the poem originally published as "Ah, Not This Granite Dead and Cold" in the Philadelphia Press on February 22, 1885. It would later be reprinted as "Washington's Monument, February, 1885" in the "Sands at Seventy" annex to Leaves of Grass (1888). This draft is written on a piece of paper with an envelope pasted at the bottom, postmarked February 18, 1885.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Washington's monument, February, 1885 : autograph manuscript drafts of the poem, [ca. 1885].
bibl.orgName: The Pierpont Morgan Library, New York
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.head: Far, far,Beyond the marblegranite dead and cold.

lg.l: Far, far,Beyond this marblegranite dead and cold

Outfar, farout from this base and shaft ere—
partly—the round earthzones circling.comprehending each & all
comprehendingly

l.add: (Thou, Wahshington art the world's. humanity's, freedom's, law's—not yours alone America.)

lg.l:
Each teems city's steets, indoors or
out factories and farms,

Wherein humanity—not yours alone
vast stretches of America

l.add:
(no lurid bane‸exceptional, nor intellect, nor conquest; domination)
Thy banes thoughby deathless waves of eniauation the
the raised consumer ownership becomes

lg.l:
Europe's, in castle or in laborers
cot—the Arab's in his tent—
the African's

Old Asia's selfthere with venerable
smile, seated amid the past,

(Greets the antique the hero new? It isTis but
the same—the same eternal
heart and arm,—the heir legitimate,

Courage, alertness, patience, hope, the
same—e'en in defeat defeated
not the same,)

l.del:
Wherein the partriot soul exists—
now or to come or past

lg.l: Each‸AllTheThrough teeming cityies' streets, indoors or our, factories of farms

Wheree'r ship sails, or house is built
on land or night or day,

l.del:
Where Washingtonthihit real is not thy monument?
There is thou monument

lg.l:
Now, or to come, or past, wheree'r
the patriot thought brains
existed or exists amid there, all these banners is of there to thee

To my soul's span
are thy‸are countries monuments.
